<headline>
Breaking News :- Greece bailout deal agreed
</headline>
<post id="p1" author="M.A.D" datetime="2015-07-13T14:03:00">
Breaking News Greece bailout deal agreed
Eurozone leaders have reached "agreement" after marathon talks over a third bailout for Greece, the Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel says.
A spokesman for the Cypriot government, Nikos Christodoulides, tweeted: "Seems we have a deal."
Details of any agreement were not immediately clear. Eurozone leaders have been meeting in Brussels for more than 16 hours.
http://www.bbc.com/news/live/business-33476597
But it’s not all over till the fat lady sings
Will the Greek parliament pass a deal?

One of the key conditions in the draft proposal is the Greek parliament rapidly passing austerity reforms. However, having just won a referendum based on rejecting austerity, it is not clear how easy a task this will be for Alexis Tsipras.
His labour minister, Panos Skourletis, has said on Greek television that it could be a hard sell for the prime minister's own anti-austerity Syriza party.
"Right now there is an issue of a governmental majority [in parliament]," Skourletis said on ERT. "I cannot easily blame anyone who cannot say 'yes' to this deal."
"We aren't trying to make this deal look better, and we are saying it clearly: this deal is not us," he added.
</post>
<post id="p2" author="outasite" datetime="2015-07-13T15:10:00">
Why can't the thief b*tch Merkel steal directly from people's bank accounts like she did in Cyprus.

I have a certain amount of sympathy for some of the Greek population but this is a country that allows hairdressers to retire on almost full pay at the age of 50, because their occupation is DANGEROUS! This is a country that allows a woman of 18 to join the civil service, work for 15 years and retire at the age of 33 on full government pension.
This is a country that allows pensions to be inherited on the death of the pension holder.
This is a country that could pay back it's debt if it could collect the taxes owed by the population.
My feeling is that the only tax they pay is their equivalent of VAT and they wouldn't pay that if they could get away with it.
And I feel that they will pay and play the absolute minimum they need to.

Having said all that, we will be going to Chania for a few days and will pump euros <img src="./images/smilies/drink1.gif" alt=":pint" title="George and Dragon"> into their economy, so that should make a difference.
</post>
